examples.en: Are you American?
examples.ja: アメリカ人ですか？

examples.en: There are two American people.
examples.ja: アメリカ人が二人います。

examples.en: Michael is a friendly American.
examples.ja: マイケルは、フレンドリーなアメリカ人だ。

meaning_mnemonic: The アメリカ part is pretty easy so long as you know katakana. It's the word for "America." You know that <kanji>人</kanji> means "person," so you can figure out that America + Person = <vocabulary>American person</vocabulary> — specifically a <vocabulary>person from the USA</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Often times, when two kanji come together to form a kanji compound (or jukugo), you use the on'yomi readings. This is similar to that, though instead of another kanji it's a foreign word. This pattern works with almost any country as well. Just add 人 to a country name and you've described the people who live there. You'll see more of these before you're finished here.

And since 人 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use: 

<vocabulary>Americans</vocabulary> absolutely love their <reading>jean</reading>s (じん), it's a well-known fact!

examples.en: There are two French people.
examples.ja: 二人のフランス人がいる。

examples.en: The chef at this restaurant is French.
examples.ja: このレストランのシェフはフランス人です。

examples.en: According to word on the street, French people apparently drink beer too.
examples.ja: ウワサによると、フランス人はビールものむらしいよ。

meaning_mnemonic: フランス is "France." So what is a "France person?" That would be a <vocabulary>French person</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Often times, when two kanji come together to form a kanji compound (or jukugo), you use the on'yomi readings. This is similar to that, though instead of another kanji it's a foreign word. This pattern works with almost any country as well. Just add 人 to a country name and you've described the people who live there. You'll see more of these before you're finished here.

And since 人 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use: 

As with all words for nationalities, the 人 here is pronounced じん. Like people of all other nationalities, a <vocabulary>French person</vocabulary> loves their <reading>jean</reading>s (じん) too!

examples.en: Marbles are small, round balls.
examples.ja: ビー玉は小さい丸い玉です。

examples.en: There is a big marble race on February 3rd.
examples.ja: 二月三日に大きなビー玉のレースがあります。

examples.en: Mom, your eyeball is beautiful like a marble.
examples.ja: ママの目玉、ビー玉みたいできれいだね。

meaning_mnemonic: When you see a katakana word, it's a safe bet that it is a foreign loan word from somewhere else. This one's interesting, because it combines katakana and kanji! The first <vocabulary>marble</vocabulary> came to Japan from Portugal, so the ビー part of the word is short for "vidro," which means "glass" in Portuguese. Anyway, don't get thrown off by that ビー. Maybe just imagine that your favorite marble is black and yellow like a bee.
reading_mnemonic: If you know katakana as well as the reading that you learned when you learned the kanji <kanji>玉</kanji>, you should be able to read this. Just watch out for the rendaku.

examples.en: I'm planning to get a toy poodle that will be born this month.
examples.ja: 今月、生まれるトイプードルをかうつもりです。

examples.en: My mother was born in the United States.
examples.ja: 母はアメリカで生まれた。

examples.en: Newborns drink milk too.
examples.ja: 生まれたばかりの子もミルクをのみますよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Since this is a kanji with hiragana attached that ends with an う sound, you know that this word is a verb. What's the ultimate verb version of the kanji 生? That would be <vocabulary>to be born</vocabulary>, the very beginning of <kanji>life</kanji> as we know it!
reading_mnemonic:
You have to remember the う part of this word to read it. To remember that, let's use a mnemonic: 

Something is about to be born, and when you lean in for a closer look… it’s an <reading>u</reading>ni (う). Yes, a sea urchin. You weren’t expecting that. Close your eyes and imagine what the process of an uni being born might look like, to help you remember this reading.

examples.en: One draft beer, please.
examples.ja: 生ビール、一つ下さい。

examples.en: Are raw peppers tasty?
examples.ja: 生のパプリカは、おいしいですか？

examples.en: Grandma has seen The Beatles in person.
examples.ja: おばあちゃんはビートルズを生でみたことがある。

meaning_mnemonic:
Normally a single kanji alone like this would mean the same thing as its parent kanji, but in the case of <kanji>生</kanji> it's a little different (but still related). When you think of something that has life, it's <vocabulary>fresh</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>raw</vocabulary>. Think sashimi or sushi, for example. You want that to be as close as possible to life as you can, so you eat it when it's fresh and raw. This word can also be used to describe a <vocabulary>live</vocabulary> event, like a concert or sporting event. 

You'll see this word at the beginning of other words. For example, 生たまご is "raw egg."
reading_mnemonic:
This uses one of the kun'yomi readings. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:

After eating <vocabulary>raw</vocabulary> fish, my yoga teacher and I say <reading>nama</reading>ste (なま) to the sushi chef, bowing low to show our appreciation.

examples.en: The population here is about 10,000.
examples.ja: ここの人口はおよそ一万人です。

examples.en: This secondhand coat was 10,000 yen.
examples.ja: この中古のコートは一万円でした。

examples.en: 10,000 meters is ten kilometers.
examples.ja: 一万メートルは十キロメートルです。

meaning_mnemonic: When you have <kanji>one</kanji> <kanji>ten thousand</kanji> you just have <vocabulary>ten thousand</vocabulary>. In Japanese, though, you specify how many ten thousands you have, though (which is weird in English, but should make sense if you think about it).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This mango cost me 20,000 yen.
examples.ja: このマンゴーは二万円もしました。

examples.en: Congratulations on twenty thousand followers!
examples.ja: 二万フォロワーおめでとうございます。

examples.en: Those sneakers cost 20,000 dollars, apparently!
examples.ja: あのスニーカー、二万ドルもしたんだって！

meaning_mnemonic: When you have <kanji>two</kanji> <kanji>ten thousand</kanji>s, you have <vocabulary>twenty thousand</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This apartment costs about 100,000 yen a month.
examples.ja: このアパートは月に十万円くらいです。

examples.en: I got 100,000 miles from a flight to New York.
examples.ja: ニューヨークへのフライトで十万マイルもらった。

examples.en: That girl has hundreds of thousands followers, apparently.
examples.ja: あの女の子、十万人もフォロワーがいるんだって。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Ten</kanji> <kanji>ten thousand</kanji>s is equal to <vocabulary>one hundred thousand</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I'm in Japan right now.
examples.ja: 今、日本にいます。

examples.en: I'm texting my mother right now.
examples.ja: 今、母にメールしてるところです。

examples.en: The queen now is very kind.
examples.ja: 今の女王は、とてもやさしい。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

What'll you drink now? I'll have a Zima, <reading>ima</reading>.

Say "ZIMA IMA" ten times fast.

examples.en: Are you free today?
examples.ja: 今日、ひま？

examples.en: I got a good score on today's test.
examples.ja: 今日のテストは、いいスコアだったよ。

examples.en: Oh my! Today is Mother's Day!
examples.ja: やばい！今日、母の日じゃん！

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>now</kanji> <kanji>day</kanji> is what day? Oh, it's <vocabulary>today</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
The reading for this word is a complete exception, though the word itself is incredibly common and useful. When you think of "today" think about what you have to do <vocabulary>today</vocabulary> for work.

You have to work in one of those mall <reading>kio</reading>sks (きょう). Just think about how sad you are that you have to do this today. What a crummy day. It's sunny outside and you're stuck in a mall manning this hermit crab kiosk.

Note: This reading mnemonic is pretty far away from the actual reading, as far as reading mnemonics go. Use this to get yourself close, and then use your own brain grapes to get the rest of the way there. This one won't be as easy as most of the others, but do some good old fashioned memorization and you should be okay. I won't ask you to do this much, fortunately. :)

examples.en: There's an important test this month.
examples.ja: 今月は大切なテストがあります。

examples.en: Please do this by the 10th of this month.
examples.ja: 今月の十日までにやって下さい。

examples.en: I'll be in Seattle this month.
examples.ja: 今月は、シアトル市にいます。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>now</kanji> <kanji>month</kanji> is actually <vocabulary>this month</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 月 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

Only <vocabulary>this month</vocabulary>, your pet <reading>con</reading>dor <reading>gets</reading> (こんげつ) to sleep in your bed. You usually keep it in a cage, but once a year, you make an exception. And that's this month. How cute!

examples.en: I’ve read halfway through this book.
examples.ja: この本を半分までよみました。

examples.en: Half of this class are girls.
examples.ja: このクラスの半分は女子です。

examples.en: About half of the Japanese are ninjas.
examples.ja: ざっくり日本人の半分ぐらいはニンジャです。

meaning_mnemonic: You have <kanji>half</kanji> a <kanji>part</kanji>. Half a part is still <vocabulary>half</vocabulary>, right?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: That's dad's portion of ice cream.
examples.ja: それはお父さんの分のアイスクリームだよ。

examples.en: The alcohol content of this whisky is forty percent.
examples.ja: このウィスキーのアルコール分は四十パーセントです。

examples.en: This city is one-third the size of Seattle.
examples.ja: この市はシアトル市の3分の1の大きさです。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word has the same meaning that you learned with the kanji: <vocabulary>part</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>portion</vocabulary>. By extension, it can also mean <vocabulary>content</vocabulary>, as in "alcohol content" because that's the portion of alcohol in a drink.

This word is used for fractions, too, as in one third or one quarter. Again, you can see how this links to "parts" and "portions", right?
reading_mnemonic:
This word is usually combined with a word or phrase indicating whose part or portion you're referring to. That's probably why this single kanji vocab word uses the on'yomi instead of the kun'yomi reading. Check out the common word combinations to see what we're talking about!

And when it means <vocabulary>part</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>portion</vocabulary>, it's read ぶん. Probably because your buns come in two parts. Ohoho.

examples.en: Friends are important.
examples.ja: 友人は大切だ。

examples.en: This is a valuable necklace.
examples.ja: これは大切なネックレスなんです。

examples.en: Please take good care of this marble.
examples.ja: このビー玉、大切にしてね。

meaning_mnemonic: Think back to the old old olden days. Back when decisions were made with swords. A <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>cut</kanji> is going to be <vocabulary>important</vocabulary>. Just imagine a couple samurai squaring off, then charging, then making one big cut. It's the most important thing they'll do in their lives (if they live!).
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 大 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

It's extremely <vocabulary>important</vocabulary> to keep your <reading>tie</reading>s in <reading>sets</reading> (たいせつ). If you don't arrange them neatly in sets, the tie police might just come knocking at your door and take you with them!

examples.en: You cut mangos with a knife.
examples.ja: マンゴーはナイフで切る。

examples.en: Did you cut that big tree with a chainsaw?
examples.ja: あの大きい木、チェーンソーで切ったんですか？

examples.en: I cut my dog's fur, and now it looks like a cow.
examples.ja: 犬の毛を切ったら牛みたいになっちゃった。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>cut</kanji>, and the verb form of that is <vocabulary>to cut</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: When you think <vocabulary>to cut</vocabulary> something, what do you think about cutting? One thing is cutting down a tree, which is also known as <reading>木</reading> (き). You 切る a 木.

examples.en: Michael is my father's friend.
examples.ja: マイケルさんは、父の友人です。

examples.en: I have an American friend.
examples.ja: アメリカ人の友人がいます。

examples.en: I tagged along on my friend's honeymoon.
examples.ja: 友人のハネムーンについてきました。

meaning_mnemonic:
A person who is a friend is just that, a <vocabulary>friend</vocabulary>!

Note that 友人 is a more formal word that’s often used in professional settings.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 人 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

All your <vocabulary>friend</vocabulary>s are <reading>you</reading>ths in <reading>jean</reading>s (ゆうじん)! Every single one. If any of your friends is not a youth in jeans, they're simply not your friend, I'm afraid.

examples.en: There were many thick trees.
examples.ja: 太い木がたくさんあった。

examples.en: Are these jeans a little thick?
examples.ja: このジーンズ、少し太いかな。

examples.en: I don't have a lot of hair, but it's thick.
examples.ja: わたしの毛は少ないけど、太いんです。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of the <kanji>fat</kanji>? It's the same: <vocabulary>fat</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is the kun'yomi reading of the kanji (because it's a single kanji, all alone with hiragana attached). You learned that reading with the kanji, so you should be good to go. But here's a mnemonic just in case:

The <vocabulary>fat</vocabulary> cat loves to curl up on the <reading>futo</reading>n (ふと) all day.

examples.en: There's a little bit of curry.
examples.ja: カレーが少しあるよ。

examples.en: Is this apartment a little small for three people?
examples.ja: このアパートは三人には少し小さいですか？

examples.en: The ketchup only comes out a little bit at a time.
examples.ja: ケチャップが少しずつしか出ない。

meaning_mnemonic: This word is a single kanji with hiragana attached, though there is no specific clue as to what type of word it is. That means you can usually guess it's a noun, adverb or na-adjective (in this case it's a noun / adverb). The meaning of this word is pretty much the same as the kanji, though, making it fairly easy. The kanji meaning for <kanji>少</kanji> is <kanji>few</kanji>, and the meaning of the vocab form is <vocabulary>a little</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>a few</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Did you know that this word created an English word you probably already know? Have you ever heard someone say "just a skosh"? That's <vocabulary>少し</vocabulary>! Hopefully you know this English word and therefore know this Japanese word as well.

examples.en: There are few Caucasians and Asians in this area.
examples.ja: このエリアには白人やアジア人は少ないです。

examples.en: Let's cherish the toilet paper as there's not much left.
examples.ja: のこり少ないトイレットペーパー、大切にしよう。

examples.en: It's not a bad thing to have few friends.
examples.ja: 友人が少ないことは、わるいことじゃない。

meaning_mnemonic: This word has a single kanji with hiragana attached, ending in a い. This means you know it's an adjective. What is the adjective form of <kanji>few</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>few</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
The reading for this one is fairly difficult, as it's the kun'yomi reading (you can tell it's kun'yomi because of all the hiragana attached). You have to remember the すく part to remember the reading of this word. Think of it this way: 

You have a <vocabulary>few</vocabulary> of something. This something is <reading>suck</reading>ers (すく). Imagine putting all (three-ish) of them in your mouth at once. How does it taste? Can you taste the flavors from each of the few?

examples.en: Vivid pink is an eye-catching color.
examples.ja: ビビッドピンクは人の目を引くカラーです。

examples.en: Pull this lever with all your strength.
examples.ja: このレバーを力いっぱい引いて。

examples.en: Ten minus two is eight, right?
examples.ja: 十引くニは八でしょ？

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>pull</kanji> and the verb version vocab means <vocabulary>to pull</vocabulary>.

This word can be transitive or intransitive. You use 引く in a transitive way to say you pull something, for example. But it can also mean <vocabulary>to withdraw</vocabulary> when you talk about things that pull back, like water that recedes, pain that subsides, soldiers that withdraw, or even your body recoiling when something puts you off.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. The reading (ひ) is the same as the one you learned for the kanji, meaning you should already know it!

examples.en: Dad has a big heart.
examples.ja: パパは心が大きい。

examples.en: Cupid's arrow struck my heart.
examples.ja: キューピッドの矢が心にささった。

examples.en: "Good morning, prince," I said in my mind.
examples.ja: 「おはよう、王子」と、心の中でいった。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

Imagine a giant <vocabulary>heart</vocabulary> sitting in a rowing boat. It's also drinking cocoa. Focus on all three of these parts and associate them into one story / memory. Once you've done that, sing the "<reading>cocoa row</reading>" (こころ) song! I don't know what that song is, but I want you to make one up and actually sing it, out loud. If you do, I bet you won't forget this word's reading too easily.

examples.en: The design of this apartment's doorway is cute.
examples.ja: このアパート、戸口のデザインがかわいいですね。

examples.en: This doorway is a little small.
examples.ja: この戸口、少し小さいね。

examples.en: Why are you always standing in the doorway?
examples.ja: なんで、ずっと戸口に立ってるの？

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>door</kanji>'s <kanji>mouth</kanji> is the <vocabulary>doorway</vocabulary>! 

戸口 is mostly used for doorways that lead outside. It has an old-fashioned feel to it and is becoming less common these days, especially in spoken Japanese.

You might notice that this word resembles 出口 (exit) and 入り口 (entrance). Like in those words, the character 口 just represents an opening here.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this one is mixed. You get the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, even though it's a combo (jukugo) kanji. Since 戸's only reading is the kun'yomi reading you should know it. Also, you should know the kun'yomi reading for 口 as well from level 1. That means as long as you remember that this is a kun'yomi fest over here, you should be able to read this word. Also watch out for the rendaku (also known as sequential voicing). That just means the く becomes the voiced ぐ.

examples.en: There is a shopping mall in the North.
examples.ja: 北の方にショッピングモールがありますよ。

examples.en: Do you know how to make chocolate cake?
examples.ja: チョコレートケーキのつくり方は分かりますか？

examples.en: Which is better?
examples.ja: どっちの方がいい？

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

You learned 方 means <vocabulary>direction</vocabulary>, but it can also mean <vocabulary>way</vocabulary>, as in この方がいい (this <vocabulary>way</vocabulary> is better) or やり方 (the <vocabulary>way</vocabulary> of doing something). 

Interestingly, 方 can also be used to refer to people politely, like こちらの方 (this person). This is because, in traditional Japanese, people—especially noble ones—were often referred to indirectly, as if indicating their presence from a direction.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading, but it can actually use kun'yomi or on'yomi depending on the context. Here are a couple mnemonics to help you remember both readings and how they're most often used:

You can always remember which <vocabulary>direction</vocabulary> your <reading>ho</reading>me (ほう) is in. It's in こっちの方 (this direction)!

And the best <vocabulary>way</vocabulary> to get there is with a <reading>cata</reading>pult (かた). Just climb in the catapult and launch yourself there — it's the best やり方.

examples.en: This is the button to stop the fire.
examples.ja: 火を止めるボタンはこれです。

examples.en: I rushed to stop the water.
examples.ja: いそいで水を止めた。

examples.en: Fugu said "Huh?," and stopped their hand cutting the tomato.
examples.ja: フグは「はっ？」といって、トマトを切る手を止めた。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>stop</kanji>, so the verb vocab version of that is <vocabulary>to stop something</vocabulary>. Alternatively, it can also mean <vocabulary>to stop doing something</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. This word has two different readings for its slightly different meanings, so here's a couple mnemonics to help remember which is which:

When you need <vocabulary>to stop something</vocabulary> from moving, you use your <reading>toe</reading> (と). For most people, this would just lead to a stubbed toe, but you have toes of iron — sturdy enough to stop even speeding locomotives in their tracks.

On the other hand, when you need <vocabulary>to stop doing something</vocabulary> — you know, a bad habit or whatnot — you call over the <reading>Ya</reading>nkees (や). Imagine the whole New York Yankees squad cheering you on (or threatening you with their bats). You'd be able to quit immediately.

examples.en: Is the karaoke contest on the 5th canceled?
examples.ja: 五日のカラオケコンテストは中止ですか？

examples.en: I'm hoping that the concert won't be canceled.
examples.ja: コンサート、中止しないでほしいな。

examples.en: Due to a scandal involving one of the members, the tour has been canceled for a while.
examples.ja: メンバーの一人にスキャンダルがあったため、ツアーはしばらく中止だ。

meaning_mnemonic: You're in the <kanji>middle</kanji> of something when someone yells "<kanji>stop</kanji>!" They hit you with a <vocabulary>cancellation</vocabulary> order and demand the immediate <vocabulary>discontinuation</vocabulary> of all your activities. Welp, it looks like you've been canceled — better go find something else to do.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This cow has a lot of hair.
examples.ja: この牛、毛がたくさんですね。

examples.en: I had hair since I was born.
examples.ja: 生まれたときから毛がありました。

examples.en: I can't wear a white shirt because of the dog fur.
examples.ja: 犬の毛のせいで白のシャツはきれないんです。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

Look down! You're holding something covered in <vocabulary>fur</vocabulary>. It's a furry <reading>ke</reading>ttle (け)! It's the weirdest kettle you've ever seen, but presumably it keeps the water hot for much longer.

examples.en: My father is German.
examples.ja: わたしの父は、ドイツ人です。

examples.en: This tie matches my father's.
examples.ja: このネクタイは、父とおそろいなんです。

examples.en: My father was a drummer.
examples.ja: 父はドラマーでした。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is the polite and humble form of <vocabulary>father</vocabulary>. You use this when you're talking about your own <vocabulary>dad</vocabulary> to other people in formal settings, especially if you aren't very close to them.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned when learning the kanji.

examples.en: I emailed my dad.
examples.ja: お父さんにメールした。

examples.en: Dad likes apples.
examples.ja: お父さんはリンゴがすきです。

examples.en: Dad, did you understand?
examples.ja: お父さん、分かった？

meaning_mnemonic:
This word begins with an honorific (お), making whatever comes after it more elevated. Then there's 父, which you know means <kanji>father</kanji>. Lastly, we have the honorific name-ender <ja>さん</ja>. So this is a nice way to say <vocabulary>father</vocabulary>. 

You'll want to use this when you're addressing or calling out to your own <vocabulary>dad</vocabulary>, or when you're talking about him or someone else's dad in a casual setting.
reading_mnemonic:
The part you have to learn to read is the 父 portion. It uses the kun'yomi, but not the one you initially learned with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember this new reading:

The thing your <vocabulary>father</vocabulary> loves the most is <reading>とう</reading>きょう. He will not stop talking about とうきょう to you, and you just have to listen. とうきょう this, とうきょう that. To really get this picture in your head, make sure to imagine your dad incessantly droning on about とうきょう.

examples.en: There are many cows.
examples.ja: 牛がたくさんいますね。

examples.en: Which would you like, a beef steak or a chicken steak?
examples.ja: 牛のステーキとチキンステーキ、どっちがいい？

examples.en: My pet is a cow.
examples.ja: うちのペットは牛です。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are the same. This word is a bit broader than <vocabulary>cow</vocabulary> though, and can also be used to be <vocabulary>bull</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>ox</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. Here's a mnemonic to help you to remember it: 

You're leading the cows around the field. To get them to move, you yell out "<reading>USH</reading>, USH, USH!" (うし) because you have a speech impediment and want to say "MUSH MUSH MUSH." Go ahead and say this out loud, yelling it if you can.

examples.en: I wear coats and jackets in winter.
examples.ja: 冬はコートとジャケットをきます。

examples.en: What's New York like in the winter?
examples.ja: 冬のニューヨークは、どうですか？

examples.en: February in Japan is winter.
examples.ja: 日本のニ月は冬ですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this word is the same as the kun'yomi reading you learned for the kanji, meaning you should know both!

examples.en: North is this way.
examples.ja: 北はこっちですよ。

examples.en: Canada is in North America.
examples.ja: カナダは北アメリカです。

examples.en: Ten police cars headed north.
examples.ja: パトカーが十台、北の方にいったよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. You already learned that reading with the kanji, so you should be good to go here!

examples.en: There's only another day and a half until the JLPT exam.
examples.ja: JLPTまで、あと一日半しかないよ。

examples.en: This child is three and a half years old.
examples.ja: この子は三才半です。

examples.en: The size of this kitchen is about two and a half meters.
examples.ja: このキッチンの大きさは、およそ二メートル半です。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it's supposed to use the kun'yomi reading. But, there is no useful kun'yomi reading for this kanji, so even the single kanji vocab word version uses the on'yomi reading, which you've already learned!

examples.en: This dress is old.
examples.ja: このドレスは古いです。

examples.en: The old tablet sold for 9,000 yen.
examples.ja: 古いタブレットが九千円でうれた。

examples.en: I like old things like antiques and whatnot.
examples.ja: アンティークとか古いものがすきなんです。

meaning_mnemonic:
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>old</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>old</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>ancient</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>out-of-date</vocabulary>.

This word is used for things like clothes, food and friendships, but not for people! So a 古い友人 (old friend) is someone you've been friends with for a long time, not an elderly friend.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji with some hiragana attached, it's going to use the kun'yomi reading. You learned the on'yomi when learning the kanji portion, so let's use a mnemonic to help you with the reading of this word: 

If you're <vocabulary>old</vocabulary>, you're also <reading>full</reading> (ふる) of memories. And you're probably full of old secrets. And you're full from old people food.

examples.en: This Benz is secondhand.
examples.ja: このベンツは中古です。

examples.en: I bought used jeans.
examples.ja: 中古でジーンズをかった。

examples.en: There are many books and manga in secondhand shops.
examples.ja: 中古ショップには本やマンガがたくさんありますよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The combination of kanji doesn't make perfect sense, but it's alright. Take something that's <kanji>middle</kanji> <kanji>old</kanji> and you have something that's <vocabulary>used</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>secondhand</vocabulary>. It's not 100% old yet... it's still in the middle, meaning you can give it to someone else to use, like your younger siblings.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: We have only one TV at home.
examples.ja: うちにはテレビが一台しかない。

examples.en: Could you call me a taxi?
examples.ja: タクシーを一台よんで下さい。

examples.en: We have fights over one gaming console.
examples.ja: うちでは一台のゲームをめぐって、ケンカがおきます。

meaning_mnemonic: As long as you know the two kanji that make up this word, you should be able to figure out the meaning of this word as well.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I gave my mother two sports cars as presents.
examples.ja: 母にスポーツカーをニ台プレゼントした。

examples.en: There are two monitors on my desk.
examples.ja: わたしのデスクにはモニターがニ台あります。

examples.en: There are many people who have two smartphones; one for work and one private.
examples.ja: しごととプライベートで、スマホをニ台もちしてる人はたくさんいる。

meaning_mnemonic: When you combine these two kanji, you should be able to see how it forms the word <vocabulary>two machines</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Five police cars came to the hotel.
examples.ja: ホテルにパトカーが五台きた。

examples.en: That girl apparently bought five tablets on her own.
examples.ja: あの女の子、一人でタブレットを五台もかったんだって。

examples.en: The highlight of the sale is coffee makers and we only have five of them.
examples.ja: セールの目玉は五台かぎりのコーヒーメーカーです。

meaning_mnemonic: As long as you know both of the individual kanji meanings, you should be able to put together this one to get <vocabulary>five machines</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I ordered ten PCs.
examples.ja: パソコンを十台オーダーした。

examples.en: There are ten security cameras in this building.
examples.ja: このビルにはセキュリティカメラが十台ある。

examples.en: There are only ten taxis in this area.
examples.ja: このエリアにはタクシーが十台しかないの。

meaning_mnemonic: If you know the two kanji separately, you should be able to put them together to form the meaning of this kanji.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Let's barbecue outside.
examples.ja: 外でバーベキューしよう。

examples.en: There is a big cherry blossom tree outside.
examples.ja: 外に大きなサクラの木があります。

examples.en: Which do you prefer, outside or inside?
examples.ja: 外と中、どっちがすき？

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Note that 外 doesn't always simply indicate the physical position of something. It can also be used figuratively to refer to what's outside of one's inner circle or home.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

You look <vocabulary>outside</vocabulary>, it's totally frozen. You throw <reading>salt</reading> (そと) outside to melt the ice.

examples.en: We had a double date with a foreign couple.
examples.ja: 外人カップルとダブルデートをした。

examples.en: There are lots of foreigners at the after party.
examples.ja: アフターパーティーには外人がたくさんいた。

examples.en: The foreigner at the bar bought me a glass of whiskey.
examples.ja: バーにいた外人さんがウィスキーをおごってくれたんです。

meaning_mnemonic: An "outside person" is a <vocabulary>foreigner</vocabulary>. This word is fairly common, though it's not super polite, either. It's okay most of the time, but it can be used derogatorily depending on the situation. The more polite version is 外国人 (outside country person) but you won't learn that until you learn the kanji for 国.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 人 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

Who's the <vocabulary>foreigner</vocabulary>? Well obviously the <reading>guy</reading> wearing <reading>jean</reading>s (がいじん)!

examples.en: What is the population of Manila City?
examples.ja: マニラ市の人口はどのくらいですか？

examples.en: Please check out the city's website.
examples.ja: 市のウェブサイトをチェックして下さい。

examples.en: Hikone City's yuruchara is "Hikonyan."
examples.ja: ひこね市のゆるキャラは、「ひこにゃん」です。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned when learning the kanji.

examples.en: You can get into the municipal pool for three dollars.
examples.ja: 市立プールは三ドルで入れるよ。

examples.en: There aren't many municipal international schools.
examples.ja: 市立のインターナショナルスクールはあまりない。

examples.en: Is there a municipal hotel in this area?
examples.ja: 市立のホテルはこのエリアにありますか？

meaning_mnemonic: When the <kanji>city</kanji> <kanji>stand</kanji>s something up, that thing becomes <vocabulary>municipal</vocabulary>. You know, like a <vocabulary>city-run</vocabulary> library or a city-run gym or something. The city is what keeps that place standing.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I live in Seattle now.
examples.ja: 今はシアトル市にすんでいます。

examples.en: My mother grew up in Seattle.
examples.ja: わたしのお母さんは、シアトル市でそだちました。

examples.en: Seattle has a baseball team called the Mariners.
examples.ja: シアトル市にはマリナーズというベースボールチームがある。

meaning_mnemonic: The name of the city (シアトル／しあとる) with a <kanji>市</kanji> attached to it means it is "the city of ____." You can do this with any city (try it out on your hometown!). So this word means <vocabulary>Seattle</vocabulary>, or more specifically <vocabulary>City of Seattle</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses on'yomi reading, which you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: This kitchen counter is very wide.
examples.ja: このキッチンカウンターすごく広いね。

examples.en: My friend's apartment is quite spacious.
examples.ja: 友人のアパートは中々広いです。

examples.en: I want to be a person with a big heart.
examples.ja: 心が広い人になりたい。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>wide</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>wide</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this word is the same as the reading you learned in the kanji section: ひろ, making this <reading>ひろ</reading>い.

examples.en: My mother is sixty-six years old.
examples.ja: 母は六十六才です。

examples.en: Mother's Day is in May.
examples.ja: 母の日は五月です。

examples.en: My mother is vegan.
examples.ja: 母はビーガンです。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they both mean mother. 母 is a formal and humble way to say "my mother" when talking to others. By using the plain form and omitting respectful language toward your own mom, you actually sound more humble, which makes a polite impression on the person you're speaking to. You wouldn't, however, use it when talking to your mom or when talking about someone else's mom — it would come off as too blunt for that!
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi reading, but this is the reading you learned with the kanji. Just remember, your <vocabulary>mother</vocabulary> is a terrible person and won't stop laughing at you: "<reading>HA HA</reading> HA HA HA!"

examples.en: Where’s mom?
examples.ja: お母さんはどこ？

examples.en: My mother is always on a kale diet.
examples.ja: うちのお母さん、いつもケールダイエットしてるんです。

examples.en: Oh, I got a LINE message from my mom.
examples.ja: あ、お母さんからLINEだ。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word begins with an honorific (お), which generally adds a nuance of respect or politeness to what comes after it. Then there's 母, which you know means <kanji>mother</kanji>. Lastly, we have the honorific name-ender さん. So this is a nice way to say <vocabulary>mother</vocabulary>. You use it when talking about the <vocabulary>mom</vocabulary>s of friends or casual acquaintances, when talking about your own mom in a casual social setting, or when talking to your own mom.

In more formal settings, you'll want to use 母 (pronounced はは) to talk about your own mom and the super respectful お母さま to talk about someone else's mom.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. You have to remember the かあ portion. Here's a mnemonic to help you to remember it: 

What does your super nice <vocabulary>mother</vocabulary> do for you (this is why you're so polite to her!)? She drives you all around in her <reading>car</reading> (かあ) taking you wherever you need to go... soccer, kendo, whatever. What a nice mother you have!

examples.en: This is a machine used for fitness training.
examples.ja: これはフィットネストレーニングに用いるマシンです。

examples.en: A manager's signature is required for the staff to use this computer.
examples.ja: スタッフがこのパソコンを用いるのにはマネジャーのサインがいります。

examples.en: Depending on the person, the tools they use are different.
examples.ja: 人によって用いるツールがちがうんです。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>task</kanji> or <kanji>use</kanji>. You can think of this verb as a more formal way to say <vocabulary>to use</vocabulary>, and that is <vocabulary>to utilize</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you to learn the もち portion of もちいる: 

What will you <vocabulary>utilize</vocabulary> to get the job done? You have <reading>mochi</reading> (もち) in your hand, so you'll use that. Now go think of some kind of imaginary task you'll complete with mochi, making it as ridiculous as possible.

examples.en: This is an archery arrow.
examples.ja: これはアーチェリーの矢です。

examples.en: A lot of arrows came out of the ground in this area.
examples.ja: このエリアの土から矢がたくさん出た。

examples.en: Cupid's arrow struck my heart.
examples.ja: ぼくのハートにキューピッドの矢がささったんです。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned when learning the kanji.

examples.en: That's a cute letter.
examples.ja: かわいい字ですね。

examples.en: Is this character "n"? Or is it "so"?
examples.ja: この字は「ン」ですか？それとも「ソ」ですか？

examples.en: Please increase the size of the character more.
examples.ja: 字の大きさを、もっと大きくしてください。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: You only learned one reading for the kanji that makes up this word, and it's the same as the reading for this word (of course). That means you should already know the reading.

examples.en: Life is wonderful.
examples.ja: 人生ってすばらしい。

examples.en: Would you be my partner for life?
examples.ja: 人生のパートナーになってくれませんか？

examples.en: Life is like a banana, you never know how long it will be.
examples.ja: 人生はバナナのようなものさ。どれだけながいのかだれもしらないのさ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji for <kanji>person</kanji> and <kanji>life</kanji> combined makes you think about human life. What is your <vocabulary>human life</vocabulary> like?
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 人 and 生 both have two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you:

Your <vocabulary>life</vocabulary> boils down to just two things: <reading>jean</reading>s and a <reading>sa</reading>ber (じんせい). Your whole life, that's all you've ever needed, jeans and a saber. What are you, some kind of American pirate?

examples.en: Jenny is British.
examples.ja: ジェニーさんはイギリス人です。

examples.en: This book was created by a team of Brits and Americans.
examples.ja: この本は、イギリス人とアメリカ人のチームがつくりました。

examples.en: Well, British people also drink coffee.
examples.ja: そりゃ、イギリス人もコーヒーをのみますよ。

meaning_mnemonic: イギリス means "Great Britain" or "United Kingdom." So what is a "Great Britain person?" You guessed it — a <vocabulary>British person</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>Brit</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Often times, when two kanji come together to form a kanji compound (or jukugo), you use the on'yomi readings. This is similar to that, though instead of another kanji it's a foreign word. This pattern works with almost any country as well. Just add 人 to a country name and you've described the people who live there. You'll see more of these before you're finished here.

And since 人 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use: 

As with all words for nationalities, the 人 here is pronounced じん. All nationalities, including <vocabulary>Brit</vocabulary>s, love <reading>jean</reading>s (じん)!

examples.en: This jacket has a lot of inside pockets.
examples.ja: このジャケット、内ポケットがいっぱいついてるよ。

examples.en: The inside of this mask is pink.
examples.ja: このマスク、内がわはピンクなんです。

examples.en: I turned what was in my heart into a message.
examples.ja: 心の内をメッセージにしました。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

When this kanji is a word on its own, it's actually very often written in hiragana. Still, the kanji version of the word is worth knowing, too!
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:

There's something inside and you wanna get to what's within. Look inside. <reading>Ooh, chee</reading>se (うち)! Your favorite. Ooh cheese, how I love you.

examples.en: There are five trucks here.
examples.ja: ここにはトラックが五台あります。

examples.en: Will fifty people fit in one bus?
examples.ja: バス一台に五十人も入りますか？

examples.en: In our house, three people share one computer.
examples.ja: うちではパソコン一台を三人でシェアしていますよ。

meaning_mnemonic: This counter is used with some kind of <kanji>machine</kanji> or device, usually a fairly large one (so nothing itty bitty). Cars are a good example of this. But it can also be used for things like computers, which were once the size of rooms, but are now nice and small. Thanks technology!
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Be sure to omit the 〜 in your answer as it is only a placeholder for a number.

examples.en: There are ten staff members.
examples.ja: スタッフは十人います。

examples.en: There are four of us in my family.
examples.ja: うちは、四人ファミリーです。

examples.en: A thousand guests are coming to the prince's wedding reception.
examples.ja: 王子のウェディングパーティーには千人のゲストがきます。

meaning_mnemonic: When you see this on a number, for example ７人 or ３人, you're using it to count people. Just remember, both 一人 and 二人 have alternative readings. From 3 and up it's just the number plus にん, like this. ５人 is ごにん, １０人 is じゅうにん, etc. This is the <vocabulary>counter for people</vocabulary>, which makes this word the <vocabulary>number of people</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a counter, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 人 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

Just think of the sheer <vocabulary>number of people</vocabulary> at <reading>Nin</reading>tendo (にん). It must be huge. This really is just a <vocabulary>counter for people</vocabulary> that work at Nintendo.

examples.en: Three girls were at the river.
examples.ja: 三人の少女が川にいた。

examples.en: The book genre I recommend is girl's manga.
examples.ja: おすすめの本のジャンルは、少女マンガです。

examples.en: She's a forty-year-old with a smile like a young a girl.
examples.ja: 少女のようなスマイルの四十才だ。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>little</kanji> <kanji>woman</kanji> is a <vocabulary>girl</vocabulary>. 

少女 is a relatively formal word that's often used in writing to describe a <vocabulary>young girl</vocabulary>, usually between childhood and adolescence (or between the ages of about five and eighteen).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The ticket to Japan was 100,000 yen.
examples.ja: 日本へのチケットは、十万円でした。

examples.en: This dome can fit fifty-thousand people.
examples.ja: このドームには五万人の人が入りますよ。

examples.en: My blog gets about twenty thousand views per month.
examples.ja: わたしのブログは月にニ万ビューほどあります。

meaning_mnemonic: When a vocab word is a single kanji without okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) it usually has the same meaning as the kanji it's spawned from. If you know the kanji meaning you'll also know the vocab meaning. It's <vocabulary>ten thousand</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: When a vocab word is a single kanji with no okurigana, it usually uses the kun'yomi reading. Numbers are an exception to this. Numbers use the on'yomi reading, which you've already learned by learning the kanji's reading! How nice!

examples.en: Hello, how are you?
examples.ja: 今日は、おげんきですか？

examples.en: "Konnichiwa" is often written in hiragana.
examples.ja: 「今日は」はひらがなでかくことの方がおおい。

examples.en: Let’s shout, "hello."
examples.ja: 大きなこえで、「今日は」といいましょう。

meaning_mnemonic:
This is a strange one. It's こんにちは, which you've probably heard before, but it's spelled using the kanji <kanji>now</kanji> and <kanji>day</kanji>. So when you say "now day!" you're really saying <vocabulary>hello</vocabulary>!

Warning! Don't mix this up with きょうは! While they may look the same, they don't mean the same thing. We will only ever ask you for こんにちは, so please try to remember that!

We usually don't use kanji for this, so don't use it when you're writing. But you'll probably run into it in the wild so it's good to know!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just be aware that the は at the end is actually the particle は so it's pronounced like わ.

examples.en: There is nothing to do today.
examples.ja: 今日は、なにも用がない。

examples.en: Don’t text me on LINE unless you have a good reason.
examples.ja: 用もないのにラインしてくんじゃねーよ。

examples.en: This is a winter jacket.
examples.ja: これは冬用のジャケットです。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: This one uses the on'yomi reading, which you've learned from the kanji already!

examples.en: That's a quiet dog.
examples.ja: 大人しい犬ですね。

examples.en: The queen was very quiet when she was little.
examples.ja: 女王は小さいころ、とても大人しかった。

examples.en: I'll be relaxing at the hotel today.
examples.ja: 今日はホテルで大人しくするよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how you learned that 大人 means "adult?" Well this is the adjective version of that. The I-adjective (see how it ends in い?). What adjective do adults want to be able to use for their own kids? They want to say they are <vocabulary>obedient</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>quiet</vocabulary> kids!
reading_mnemonic: You already learned this reading when you learned 大人! You should be able to read this too!

examples.en: I knocked on the door.
examples.ja: 戸をノックした。

examples.en: My cat scratches the door.
examples.ja: うちのネコは戸をカリカリします。

examples.en: This door opens and closes hard.
examples.ja: この戸は立てつけがわるい。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>door</kanji> is a <vocabulary>door</vocabulary> — the kanji and the word are exactly the same.

戸 can refer to any kind of door, but it's more commonly used for <vocabulary>sliding door</vocabulary>s, since those are the traditional style of doors in Japan. For Western-style or high-tech doors, people tend to just say ドア.
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: That woman over there? That's Mami.
examples.ja: あの女の人？マミさんだよ。

examples.en: There are many female staff at this restaurant.
examples.ja: このレストランには女の人のスタッフがたくさんいます。

examples.en: I would love to be able to email with women well.
examples.ja: 女の人と上手にメールができるようになりたいなあ。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>woman</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is a <vocabulary>woman</vocabulary>.

The の particle here means the first noun is modifying the second one, so you can probably see why 女の人 (a woman person) really just means woman! It's more polite than saying 女 by itself, so that's all you have to remember.
reading_mnemonic: This word is actually two separate words combined with a particle. So, since you treat them like separate words, you read each of them with the kun'yomi readings (they are both single kanji words all alone). That being said, in level 1 you learned about the vocab readings for these separate words, so use that knowledge to remember the reading for this word as well.

examples.en: It was water that spread the virus in Japan.
examples.ja: 日本にそのウィルスを広げたのは水だった。

examples.en: Three adults unfolded a blanket.
examples.ja: 大人三人でブランケットを広げた。

examples.en: As soon as I went inside, I opened the book.
examples.ja: 中に入ってすぐ本を広げた。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. 

The kanji itself means <kanji>wide</kanji>, and the verb version is what happens when you try to make something wider. How do you make something wider? That's right, you have <vocabulary>to spread something</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to unfold something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to open something up</vocabulary>. All of those actions will make a thing wider!

This is a transitive verb. That means it takes a direct object. You spread something. Like a newspaper, or a cloth on a table.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, but here's a reminder mnemonic to help you:

You are going <vocabulary>to spread something</vocabulary>. What are you going to spread? How about your arms, so that you can fly into the sky like the super <reading>hero</reading> (ひろ) that you are! Most heroes can fly when they spread their arms wide!

examples.en: That's a mountain echo. Can you hear it?
examples.ja: 山びこだ！きこえる？

examples.en: It was a restaurant named "Mountain Echo."
examples.ja: それは、「山びこ」というレストランでした。

examples.en: The mountain echo was so loud last night I couldn't sleep.
examples.ja: 夕べは山びこがうるさくて、ねれなかったよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
You know that 山 means mountain. Add the hiragana びこ to the end and this gives you <vocabulary>echo</vocabulary>. That's because bee children (bee 子) love echos, especially <vocabulary>mountain echo</vocabulary>s! Imagine baby bees buzzing as loudly as they can and hearing their voices echoing back at them through the mountains.

As the kanji suggests, 山びこ is generally used to describe the echo you get if you shout in the mountains. To describe other types of echo, you can use the katakana word エコー.

By the way, there is actually a kanji for the second part of this word, but it's so rare that it's usually written in kana!
reading_mnemonic: You learned this kanji reading when you learned the vocabulary 山.

examples.en: The book is on the table.
examples.ja: 本はテーブルの上にあります。

examples.en: Please put three glasses on the table.
examples.ja: テーブルの上にグラスを三つおいてください。

examples.en: I cleaned the table earlier.
examples.ja: さっき、テーブルの上をきれいにしたよ。

meaning_mnemonic: First we have a katakana word, so it's safe to assume that it's a loan word. Like many loan words, it comes from English. Say it out loud and what do you have? That's right, "table". Then comes the particle の, which joins two nouns together. Finally we have 上, which you learned means "up" or "above". Put all of these pieces together and we have a phrase meaning <vocabulary>on the table</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>tabletop</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: In this phrase, 上 is a standalone word, so it uses the same reading that you learned when you learned the vocabulary. Easy to stay on top of that one, right?

examples.en: There are many manga under the bed.
examples.ja: ベッドの下にはマンガがたくさんあります。

examples.en: I don't mop under the bed.
examples.ja: ベッドの下はモップをしないんです。

examples.en: Woah, there's someone under the bed!
examples.ja: うわっ、ベッドの下に人がいる！

meaning_mnemonic: This starts with another katakana word, so you can assume that it's a loan word. This one also comes from English. Can you figure out what it means? That's right, "bed". Then comes the particle の, which joins two nouns together. Finally, we have 下, which you learned means "down" or "below". Put these elements together and you get <vocabulary>below the bed</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>under the bed</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>beneath the bed</vocabulary>. What's under your bed?
reading_mnemonic: 下 is a standalone word here, so it uses the same reading that you learned when you learned the vocabulary.

examples.en: Then I watched the sunrise from Mt. Fuji.
examples.ja: そして、ふじ山から日の出をみました。

examples.en: It's almost sunrise!
examples.ja: もうすぐ日の出だ！

examples.en: It was a beautiful sunrise.
examples.ja: きれいな日の出だったね。

meaning_mnemonic: What do we call the <kanji>sun</kanji>'s <kanji>exit</kanji> from the horizon? That'll be the <vocabulary>sunrise</vocabulary>. Imagine the sun exiting the horizon and climbing up into the sky.
reading_mnemonic: This uses the kanji's kun'yomi readings, which you've already learned. As long as you remember those, you should be good to go!

examples.en: One draft beer, please.
examples.ja: 生ビール、一つ下さい。

examples.en: This is a draft beer dispenser.
examples.ja: これは生ビールのサーバーです。

examples.en: Can I get a draft beer to go?
examples.ja: 生ビールはテイクアウトできますか？

meaning_mnemonic:
You just learned the vocab 生, meaning fresh. Combined with the katakana word for beer makes this draft beer or unpasteurized beer.

Note that while in a lot of countries, "draft beer" refers only to beer that's drawn from a keg, 生ビール can also refer to unpasteurized canned or bottled beer, giving it a shorter shelf-life, but also keeping it fresh.
reading_mnemonic: Be careful to use kun'yomi for 生 here. Other than that, as long as you know your katakana, you should be good to go!

examples.en: I'm at the north exit!
examples.ja: 北口にいるよ！

examples.en: The convenience store is located at the north exit.
examples.ja: コンビニは北口にあります。

examples.en: Can you message me when you get to the north exit?
examples.ja: 北口についたら、メールしてくれる？

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 入り口 means "entrance" and 出口 means "exit"? This vocab is just the 口 part with a direction added to it. This also makes it both an entrance or exit. So when you have the kanji for <kanji>north</kanji>, it makes this both a <vocabulary>north exit</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>north entrance</vocabulary>. This is a great word to know if you need to know which side of a train station you need to leave on to go somewhere or meet someone!
reading_mnemonic: Just like 入り口 and 出口, this also uses kun'yomi readings. And just like before, watch out for the rendaku that changes くち to ぐち!

examples.en: This one is Mt Fuji.
examples.ja: これがふじ山です。

examples.en: This is a pen.
examples.ja: これはペンです。

examples.en: Give me two of these, please.
examples.ja: これを二つ下さい。

meaning_mnemonic:
<reading>Colle</reading>ct (これ) <vocabulary>this one</vocabulary> right here! Go ahead, collect this one.

You can use これ to talk about anything that's close to you. Things that are close to you are easy to collect, after all!

examples.en: What do you want to do for Christmas?
examples.ja: クリスマス、どうする？

examples.en: If you don't, someone else will.
examples.ja: あなたがしなくても、だれかがするよ。

examples.en: Shoot there with all your might.
examples.ja: そこで、力いっぱいシュートをするんだ。

meaning_mnemonic:
It's only <reading>through</reading> (する) doing things that we get better at them, so you need <vocabulary>to do</vocabulary> them as much as you can.

する basically means <vocabulary>to do</vocabulary>, but it’s incredibly versatile and goes beyond its English equivalent. Besides being used alone, it can be put together with a whole range of nouns to turn them into verbs. We call these する verbs and you'll learn a lot of them as we go along!

examples.en: Two apple juices, please.
examples.ja: リンゴジュース、二つ下さい。

examples.en: Do you want an apple or a banana?
examples.ja: リンゴかバナナ、いる？

examples.en: This apple tastes bad!
examples.ja: このリンゴ、まずい！

meaning_mnemonic:
<reading>Ringo</reading> (リンゴ) just ate your <vocabulary>apple</vocabulary>! You were about to take a bite, and he grabbed it. What is Ringo doing snatching apples? Surely he can afford his own.

Did you know that Ringo Starr once appeared in a Japanese TV commercial for <vocabulary>apple</vocabulary> juice? That might help you remember this word, too!

リンゴ is also commonly written in hiragana, and even in kanji, but you’ll probably see it in katakana the most.

examples.en: Do you want a cup of coffee?
examples.ja: コーヒー、のむ？

examples.en: Should we have a coffee break soon?
examples.ja: そろそろコーヒーブレークにする？

examples.en: One hot coffee, please.
examples.ja: ホットコーヒー、一つ下さい。

meaning_mnemonic:
コーヒー is the katakana version of the English word <vocabulary>coffee</vocabulary>. 

Just watch out for the second syllable, which changes to ヒー in Japanese.

examples.en: Hello Sensei.
examples.ja: 先生、こんにちは。

examples.en: Hello Aya.
examples.ja: アヤちゃん、こんにちは。

examples.en: Hello, I'm Jenny.
examples.ja: こんにちは、ジェニーです。

meaning_mnemonic:
<reading>Connie Chihua</reading>hua (こんにちは) says <vocabulary>hello</vocabulary>. Connie Chihuahua is an amazing talking chihuahua. She can only say "hello", but that alone is pretty impressive.

こんにちは is a formal way to say "hello". It’s generally used during the daytime, from late morning to early evening. Watch out for the は on the end, which is always pronounced わ.

examples.en: When will you do it?
examples.ja: いつするの？

examples.en: Until when are you in the U.S.?
examples.ja: いつまでアメリカ？

examples.en: From when will you be in Canada?
examples.ja: いつからカナダ？

meaning_mnemonic:
He <reading>eats</reading> (いつ) and eats and eats. <vocabulary>When</vocabulary> does this guy not eat?

いつ is a question word that is used to ask <vocabulary>when</vocabulary>.

examples.en: The woman stood under the light of the lamp.
examples.ja: 女はランプの明かりの下に立った。

examples.en: There's not much light around here.
examples.ja: この辺は明かりが少ない。

examples.en: It seems like we can camp with only the moonlight today.
examples.ja: 今日は月の明かりだけで、キャンプができそうです。

meaning_mnemonic:
What makes it <kanji>bright</kanji> around here? It's <vocabulary>light</vocabulary>!

Note: 明かり is mostly used for light coming from a specific source, like a lamp or light bulb. You'll learn a more general word for light in a couple levels.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You already know the reading from the kanji!
